comments.commentBody: So 911 was NOT caused by Iraq nor Afghanistan. We kill hundreds of thousands of innocent people in these countries under false pretense of war and national interest.  This immature confused young man decides to desert. He is horridly imprisoned and tortured.  Now we want to crucify him.  Wow am I less than proud of our countries response to what has happened.

Will we ever discover which pilot was still in the cockpit? If the pilot who pounded on the door can be heard clearly on the recording, perhaps he can be heard shouting the name of the one inside the cockpit. Medical records and prescription medications could be obtained to try to shed light on what may have incapacitated the one in control of the aircraft or whether he had reason to be suicidal. I hate even imagining such a scenario, but the investigators must find answers. He also could have been incapacitated by a stroke, heart attack, aneurysm or embolism.
Pilots are permitted to take antidepressants.

From Bloomberg Business: "Like the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration, the European Aviation Safety Authority doesn’t require routine mental-fitness tests. Such assessments can be ordered if examiners find cause for concern during periodic physicals that include a discussion of mental wellbeing, according to the agencies’ guidelines.

The United Nations’ International Civil Aviation Organization says psychological testing of aircrew members is rarely of value as a screening tool before a pilot is hired, according to the agency’s Manual of Civil Aviation Medicine."

Seriously?

This was so very horrific, and such a tragedy. There was a maintenance check of the plane just the day before. Depressurization, beginning or only in the cockpit, seems a likely scenario. What else but something like that could explain the second pilot never responding. "The airline has not disclosed the identities of the pilots, except to say that the captain was a 10-year veteran." Still, it felt a bit odd that the article never mentions any discussion of whomever was left in the cockpit, and what could or might have been happening w them.
Immeasurably sad. May the souls of the innocent people on board, babies, children, artists and all, rest in peace.
Because it wasn't you in the cockpit.

So the other pilot does not have a means to enter a locked cockpit in an emergency? This is a deliberate act of taking the plane down. The fact are structured in this mode. Otherwise the second pilot would have been able to access the controls.
Not if it is a lone wolf suicide by pilot type. Like the Airbus that went into the Atlantic outside NYC a while back. Almost an identical scenario.
Nope. Cockpit doors only can be opened from inside the cockpit. There is no way of opening it from outside, which is very tragic in this case.

What real difference would that have made?  This appears it might  be pilot suicide and most experts think MH370 likely also was too.  The only difference your suggestion would make is that someone on the ground could watch the unstoppable event happen live.

If a pilot can open a cockpit door from the cabin through the use of a keypad, then the cockpit is most certainly never secure. Example: Pilot comes out of the head and a terrorist has a box knife at the throat of a flight attendant and tells him to unlock the door.  All that security for nothing.
after 9/11, I think, yes.
I think he would have had to deactivate the autopilot. Others here claim that the pilot has a code to enter, which can be overridden by the pilot still in the cockpit.

There was only one pilot flying the plane, the other pilot was locked out, the pilot flying the plane doesn't say anything, the plane went into a slow descent and doesn't seem to have radically veered off course. Doesn't it seem like the pilot had a heart attack or aneurism or was otherwise incapacitated for health reasons? I have no idea about cockpits and flying planes, but the typical cinema image would be pilot slumped over in his seat pushing the controls in a way that sends the plane down, no? Obviously far too early, but this was my thought as I read this article.

The issue of a pilot's mental health needs to be placed on the front burner.
Pilot suicide is probably under estimated and needs to be discussed openly by those in charge.

Awful!  A friend having just returned from London a few hours ago read this latest news on the phone, and my first reaction was that the pilot may have had an heart attack.  Far more experienced, she mentioned the possibility of a broken window.  It is a terrible tragedy, a shock, and sinister, as other people have suggested, when the world has veered its eyes on the disappearance of a Malaysian flight off the radar, followed by the recent crash of the second one, and joining many others in extending to the friends and families of the victims of this latest catastrophe, deepest condolences during this time of sorrow and loss.

I am aware of two cases in recent years of commercial airline pilots deliberately crashing their planes.  So, if there were a secret signal mechanism, it would offer no solution to one suicide pilot.  Locking one pilot out of the cockpit suggests this scenario.
What about a forgotten pin code?
A regulation requires at least one flight-crew member to be seated at the controls at all times.

Memo to NHTSA and state legislatures:
Ban these menaces under threat of heavy fines, insurance hikes, and loss of license. It infuriates me that I have to share the road with teens who cross the centerline. That could be me and my family coming the other way.
Speaking as a retired MP with a lot of experience in the military justice system I would like to point out that Berghdal was always a soldier in the eyes of the Army.  He was reported in MIA status.
I have no "empathy" for a deserter. It's the military, not a Montessori kindergarten. Bergdahl knew the rules.
The 5 released Taliban have been in the secure custody of Qatar since they were transferred out of Gitmo.

We have to consider the squishy elements of cultural capital.  Improving physical capital by governmental programs won't work unless the inhabitants can observe bourgeois norms in their behavior.  Without these traits the war is lost.
Bergdahl would not be my son. But if he were, I'd wash my hands of him.

It seems the issue of this man's fate is political, which may, in this case, help deliver are more sane and wise resolution, since most people I have spoken too tend to feel he's been through enough and deserves at most, a dishonorable discharge. The soldiers in his unit probably lied about people dying in the search out of anger. But in the business those spreading the stories are probably motivated by politics.

Many people make poor choices in the military. As a nation we reclaim our own and try them in American courts. He was found, brought back, and he will be tried. Let the courts decide his fate. To not retrieve him, to find him guilty outside a court of law, to not allow due process is unAmerican. Let the Taliban commit those atrocities, not us.
He was an adult when he signed up. Then he deserted. This is not complicated. Once you join the military, you are subject to the UCMJ. This is about as cut and dried as it gets.
